speaker: Hous E Of Representatives. The Thursday, 27 May, 19s0. Took The Chair At 7 P.m., And Read Prayers. Prince Journment Of The House On Friday Last, It Was Agreed That The Address To His Royal Highness Tho Prince Of Wales Should He Presented By Mr Speaker In The Library, No Arrangement At That Time Having Heen Made By Another Place For The Adoption Of An Address. A Special Meeting Was, However, Subsequently Summoned For This Evening For That Pnroose, And, Owing To The Method Of Procedure Proposed ,To He Adopted, There, It Became Advisable, In The Opinion Of The Government, To Vary The Programme Regarding The Place Of Presentation, Which, In The Altered Cir
theText: cumstances, it was thought ought to he this chamber. I therefore, at the request of the Prime Minister, summoned this 1 special meeting for. the purpose. Motions in the same terms as those passed at the last sitting of the 'House will be submitted, giving leave of absence to all honorahle members, and providing for the adjournment of the House to a date to he fixed by Mr Speaker. These motions are required owing to the present sitting of the House. Should an interval elapse bofore the arrival o* His Hoyal Highness, I may temporarily vacate the chair, resuming it when ithe Prince is approaching. The Prime Minister will announce the arrival of-His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, whereupon I shall welcome His Royal Highness, and invite him to take a seat on the dais beside the Speaker's chair. On the entrance of the Prince, and during his presence in the chamber, honourable members will be invited to stand. I shall then read the Address of Welcome, to which His Royal Highness will make a reply. The Prime Minister will then move " That the House do now adjourn," which motion being carried, I shall ask Ministers, Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the Country party, the other members then present, and the officers of Hie House, to come forward to he presented. After presentation, they will pass behind the Speaker's chair, and places at the dining table, prior to' the entering the Hall. I , with the Prime Minister, will then accompany His Royal Highness to the door of the House. LEAVE OF ABSENCE. ister for the Navy and Acting Treasurer) [7.6] -Thes e pleasant proceedings make a break in the continuity of our sittings, and require that we should pass again two motions which, because of this happy bringing 'together of .the 'House, have lapsed. Honourable member's will recollect that before we adjourned on Friday two proposals were brought before the House and carried, one giving leave of absence to honourable members until the calling together of -the House, and the other adjourning the. House until summoned by Mr Speaker. These, now lapse, and must he re-passed to become, effective. I accordingly move That leave of absence be given to every member of the House of Bepresentatives from the determination of this sitting of the House to the date of its next sitting. Question resolved in the affirmative.

title: Prince Of Wales

speaker: Mr Speaker Then Read And Pre
theText: HIS ROYAL HIGHNESS was pleased to make the following reply:Mr Speaker and Gentlemen of the House of Representatives, "I deeply appreciate the cordial address of welcome which you have presented to me, and I shall he happy to assure my father, the Ring, of your devotion to his. Throne. The Australian nation has passed through nineteen years of development since His Majesty inaugurated the first Australian Parliament;' hut the severest of all ordeals has como upon you in the last five years, and splendidly you stood the test. I congratulate you, and through you all the great people which you represent, on your gallant services to the cause of freedom and right during the long world-war. It is a pleasure to me to know that some of my old acquaintances in the field are now amongst you here. " I shall be grateful, gentlemen, if you will let me express through you to all the Oommonwealth my keen pleasure at being here in Australia at last. I have long looked forward ,to this visit, and the magnificent welcome accorded mo has made the happiest possible 'beginning for my tour. I hope that I may see many of yon 'again during my travels through the Commonwealth." The House adjourned at 7.24 p.m., and Ministers, members, the clerks of the House, and Hansard officers in attendance were then presented by Mr .Speaker, to His Royal Highness.
title: Prince Of Wales
